content.intro:
Picture postcard perfect? The reality is even more extraordinary, exotic, and surprising. Travellers who have experienced this earthly and marine paradise can only think of going back.

Papeete and Tahiti International Airport are the doorway to a world of natural beauty, cultural wealth, simple joys and pure emotions. This is the entrance to the five archipelagos and 118 islands of French Polynesia. It would be a shame not to walk through the door! You will be struck by the sheer force of attraction exerted by a maritime region as vast as Europe and only consisting of 4,000 sqkm of land. But what land! Brilliant jewels of the ocean, miniature Eden gardens hidden in the vastness, and a whole host of little gems that are sure to leave an impression.

The magnificence of Polynesia lies in its diversity. Tahiti and her sisters reflect the life stages of a volcanic island lost in the waves. From abrupt emergence, like the Marquesas, to the age of reason, like Bora Bora and Moorea; from lagoons to mountains to flat sand atolls, like the Tuamotu Archipelago. One begins in the lagoon, and at the end of the geological phenomenon, in a coral reef with motus outcroppings - these minimalist islands of white sand and coconut trees are enough to make us all happy travellers.

However, relaxation is not always an end in itself. Not that this is a problem: water and winter sports are practiced throughout Polynesia in a spirit of excellence, from scuba diving and surfing to traditional canoe races - the best spots and world events can be found here.

Outside these exceptional sporting events there is no risk of overcrowding in Polynesia. The archipelagos are renowned for their high-quality tourism and idyllic holidays. Thanks to the caring hospitality of the Polynesians, the dream becomes reality. A reality where the good life, exploring, and a complete surrendering to the present takes full form. However, it is fascinating to delve into the past to discover the cultural and religious heritage of the islands, which was originally conquered by the Ma'ohi people. What a thrill to share the fervour of Polynesians for dance, songs, music, sculpture! And why not succumb to tattoo art, which was invented here? It will seem so obvious when you finally leave: you can truly say you have Polynesia in your skin.

content.title: Hei Restaurant, a passion for authenticity

introduction.small: It has taken next to no time for the restaurant of young chef Heiarii Hoiore to become a go-to for any foodie looking for creative, Polynesian-inspired cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hei Restaurant, a passion for authenticity

paragraphs.text:
The son of a Tahitian pastor, Heiarii Hoiore has only ever wanted one thing: to bring others joy by cooking for them. After earning his stripes in the south of France alongside the Michelin-starred Pourcel, brothers, Heiarii continued his training by taking the reins at one of Papeete's most well-known restaurants. At 35, he finally achieved his lifelong dream: opening his very own “Hei Restaurant”, where his guiding philosophy is to offer sophisticated, authentic “bistronomy”: in other words, to put a fresh new twist on classic bistro dishes.

Hei has been so successful that ever since it opened, the restaurant – with its deliberately Zen décor – has never once been empty. The secret to this success is undoubtedly its irrefutable simplicity: a single five-course menu that changes on the first Friday of every month. To start, you may be tempted by Little Tahitian shrimp ravioli with a foie gras sauce, followed by Patagonian toothfish – a fish loved by gourmets for its soft, white meat – with braised courgettes, pistachio crumb, and a salty preserved lemon jus. To finish on a high, the “Hei-style” chocolate mousse is a thing of beauty. Regulars will tell you that there is no better restaurant to be found in the whole of Polynesia.

Hei Restaurant

(Paofai seafront, opposite the gardens)

introduction.small: The Bora Bora Turtle Center educates visitors about protecting the lagoon ecosystem and the turtles that go there. The keenest visitors can even be a caretaker for a day.

paragraphs.text:
When a guest at the Le Méridien Bora Bora brought back an injured turtle one day in 2000, the hotel decided to open a turtle protection centre. Two endangered marine species – the green turtle and the hawksbill turtle – live in the lagoon, which has become a sanctuary for them as they are both endangered species. Some have lost weight because they swallowed plastic, while others need stitches. The centre cares for them, and even offers guests the chance to volunteer to help out caretakers for a day: from feeding recovering turtles, to checking the lagoon for sick animals and more. In all, the centre has saved and released 400 turtles back into the ocean.

Visitors can also just watch the turtles from an underwater observatory and see them being fed breakfast every morning. In 2012 the hotel went one step further and created an Ecology Centre, which works to protect and regenerate the turtles' natural home: the coral reef.

content.title: Pointe Vénus lighthouse: history with a panoramic view

introduction.small: At the northernmost tip of Tahiti, Pointe Vénus and its black sandy beach are towered by a historical monument: the very first lighthouse erected in the Southern Pacific.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pointe Vénus lighthouse: history with a panoramic view

paragraphs.text:
Pointe Vénus, its emerald-blue waters, black sandy beach and… its lighthouse. The place was named after British explorer and navigator James Cook, who built an observatory there in 1770 to study Venus' trajectory. Surprisingly, this breathtaking postcard-worthy landscape is still little known, in spite of its historic past. Erected more than 150 years ago, the lighthouse is quite recognisable with its singular architecture: the 25m-high square tower was put together in 1867 by Mangarevian workers. Back then, it was the very first lighthouse in the Southern Pacific, and it is still active today. It took its only break during World War II: to shed the doubt in the Japanese navy who had planned to land on its coast, islanders had camouflaged the construct (at the time surrounded with coconut groves) with painted coconut trees on its four sides.

Despite various renovation projects – the lighthouse is now fully automated – access to the inside of the building is still forbidden to the public. You will however be able to explore its surroundings: Pointe Vénus is first and foremost a vacation resort for Polynesian families out on Sundays. Its views over the Tahitian coast, dugout canoe races and, in the distance, Moorea panorama, are all very enticing.

Pointe Vénus lighthouse
98709 Mahina

introduction.small: Explore Polynesian history at the Maeva archaeological site, which gathers about twenty marae, spiritual and social artefacts of Huahine Island's royal past.

paragraphs.text:
At the entrance of the village of Maeva on Huahine Island, traces of the past tell the truth about Polynesian culture and history. The archaeological site, which used to house royal families, consists in about twenty stone marae, these places of worship where men and spiritual powers came together through local traditions. There, you will discover both authentic and reconstructed remains of fortress walls. Wandering through the signs of Polynesia's past is like visiting an open-air museum, bordering the lagoon. The high point of the visit will undoubtedly be the Manunu marae, built with two-metre high and 40m-long flat stones dating back to the 16th century.

Typical gathering place back then, a fare has been assembled in order to give you a glimpse of the period. These remnants of the past tell of the will of royal powers of the time, building lasting fare when most are still made of wood today. The fare pote'e, large shack made of thatch that opens onto the lagoon, tells this story by way of everyday items, embodying a lifestyle: paddles, pendants made of fish teeth and tattooing brushes. A rare site that tells of a little-known slice of history.

Maeva archaeological site
Opu Nui

introduction.small: Among the oldest institutions of the Polynesian archipelago, the Papeete market is a must to delve into local culture.

paragraphs.text:
Probably one of the liveliest places in town, the Papeete market has remained authentic and shows the various aspects of Polynesian culture, historical first, at it counts among the oldest institutions in activity on the archipelago. Some 500,000 people sift through its alleyways each year! Over 7,000 sqm, feel its charm and take in the flurry of activity.

This vibrant covered market is also the cultural and social centre of Papeete. Merchants have come from the entire island to gather behind the stalls. Fish, fruits, vegetables, spices, oils and deli food represent a large part of local gastronomic traditions, while craft – textiles, shell necklaces – will take you further into Polynesian daily life. The market is open every day and is most animated from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. However, the high point is still the Sunday morning, when stalls are allowed to be set outside. Expect a unique atmosphere, starting as soon as daybreak!

Papeete market

content.title: Tahiti La Plage, eco-dinner and a view over Moorea

introduction.small: Between the sand and the vastness of the sea, and with the island of Moorea in the backdrop, Tahiti La Plage is a restaurant that enjoys idyllic scenery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tahiti La Plage, eco-dinner and a view over Moorea

paragraphs.text:
Halfway between restaurant and beach, cocktail bar and nighttime concert venue, the Tahiti La Plage hybrid concept is quite seductive, offering postcard-worthy panorama. Located by the wide spreads of black sands in the Sapinus Bay, the restaurant welcomes you with simplicity and elegance. The Sauvages, Thierry and Bénédicte, have radically transformed Le Coco's, their gastronomic restaurant, into a more affordable and environmentally harmonious establishment. Dishes are dictated by the products, often locally and organically sourced with sustainable development in mind. You will always be able to trace the origin of what you eat.

The beach brasserie style is very much spoken for, with bowls, burgers, barbecued meat and fish, as well as the must-try grilled prawns. Give the chipirons à la plancha a try, cooked with garlic and Espelette pepper, then carry on with the sweet and sour Sapinus Burger (homemade bun, fish & chips, roasted pineapple, caramelised shallots, tomatoes, cucumber and wasabi mayo). End the meal with a sweet Coco Bowl consisting in a tropical mix of flambeed banana, coconut mousse, puffed caramel and roasted coconut. In the distance, the sun sets over Moorea and everything feels perfect.

Tahiti La Plage

Tahiti

https://tahitilaplage.com/fr/home/

content.title: Ròhòtu Fâre, discretion presides to a heavenly stay

introduction.small: In the heart of the Polynesian Islands, by the Baie de Povai, Ròhòtu Fâre stands out with its small bungalows, hidden amid a lush exotic garden.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ròhòtu Fâre, discretion presides to a heavenly stay

paragraphs.text:
In the midst of Bora Bora's lush vegetation, Ròhòtu Fâre delicately sings Polynesia's praise. Its private wooden bungalows with coconut tree leaves roofing are located 250m from the lagoon and offer a panoramic view over the Baie de Povai. On the premises, Oceanian Art is given pride of place with solid wood sculptures and paintings of Polynesian life scenes. Among the villas available, one is specifically adapted to welcoming families, being three times larger, with two separate bedrooms.
From your terrace, admire the natural beauties spreading all around you. Hop on a bike (provided for free by Nir, the owner) and wander around the lagoon, or delve deeper inland, in the jungle of this earthly paradise. A haven of peace both discreet and romantic, at the foot of the volcanic mountain. Just like the Mona Lisa, it will watch over you, wherever you stand.

introduction.small: With its heavenly decor and a panoramic view of the Moorea Island, Le Lotus offers an extraordinary setting for refined cuisine.

paragraphs.text:
In Tahiti, Le Lotus stands from other restaurants by offering an unusual and dreamlike kind of experience. For an unforgettable dinner by the water, you will take a seat in a lounge room on stilts, which you can access through a small wooden footbridge above the ocean. Under the dried-up pandan tree leaf roofing, you will relax and take in the incredible landscape that stretches right in front of you. Closest are the lagoon and the Faa'a reef, and – although sometimes shrouded by clouds – the magnificent Moorea Island can be seen in the background.
This careful arrangement perfectly marries with the menu, specialised in seafood. Try the rock lobster ravioli and its crustacean broth, or the smoked tuna and ginger-oil-marinated-scallops carpaccio. At lunchtime, take a dip in the hotel's swimming pool, only a stone's throw from the stilts. A perfect spot to lounge and enjoy the view.

content.title: Vaipahi's Water Gardens, heaven on earth

introduction.small: Whether for an athletic hike or a contemplative break, you can decide which path you will take to the Water Gardens of Vaipahi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Vaipahi's Water Gardens, heaven on earth

paragraphs.text:
A sacred place for Tahiti's southern coast islanders, truly unique in Polynesia, the Water Gardens of Vaipahi offer a concentration of tropical plants, both local and foreign. Revel in the beauty of the flora and magnificent landscapes consisting in springs, streams, pools and waterfalls. The Waters of Vaipahi were once a required rite of passage to purify the deceased souls of the Great Teva, the ancestral island's clan.
Adventurous explorers will be able to take full advantage of this paradisiacal site on one of the three paths available: the river trail (2 km / 1.2 mile or a one-hour walk), the middle loop (2.736 km / 1.7 mile or a 75-minute walk) and the large loop (5.125 km / 3.1 mile or a two-hour walk). You will go up marked trails, down paths lined with Caribbean pines and climb up ropes where the inclines are steepest. Later on, you will come back down to enjoy an invigorating break in the shade of the tropical gardens.

Water Gardens of Vaipahi
Mataiea District

98726 Teva I Uta
Tahiti

https://www.service-public.pf/sdt/sites-touristiques/vaipahi/

content.title: Les Relais de Joséphine for dolphin watching

introduction.small: Facing Tiputa Pass, on the island of Rangiroa, this friendly pension has a ringside seat to watch the ballet of the cetaceans.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Relais de Joséphine for dolphin watching

paragraphs.text:
Excellent example of a small Polynesian hotel, affordable and welcoming than grander establishments, this also has the advantage of being ideally positioned where the reef ends: twice a day, the tide changes direction in the pass and dozens of dolphins take the opportunity to put on an acrobatic show.

An extraordinary spectacle that you will admire while reclining comfortably in your deckchair, or settled in one of three bungalows on the beachfront. Four others are in the tropical garden, more withdrawn, but all inspired by traditional Polynesian architecture, as is the bar and the restaurant, which serves up excellent French cuisine with local products. In accordance with its homely guesthouse concept, dinner is served at the host's own table, paired with Rangiroa wines. And yet, the most dreamlike moment could very well be at breakfast, served on the terrace by Tiputa pass. Waking up with a dolphin dance, what more could you ask for?

content.title: Les Tipaniers, right on the water

introduction.small: The hotel, composed of bungalows, is ideally located in the southwest of the island, near a white sand beach with a water sports centre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Tipaniers, right on the water

paragraphs.text:
While its name is the local word for frangipani, the establishment is instead turned to the ocean and its resources. Water sports abound here: diving with rays and sharks; whale watching; sea kayaking; stand up paddle boarding, and more. In the evening, enjoy relaxing in one of 22 bungalows, with or without kitchen, in the garden or near the beach. Alternatively, for smaller budgets, four inexpensive rooms are available, giving onto the green garden located behind the hotel lobby, and merely 100 metres away from the shore.

From morning till night, the two bar-restaurants at Les Tipaniers will welcome you for drinks or a full romantic dinner experience with gastronomic menu and the ocean in the backdrop. Cherry on top, expect live music on Friday and Saturday evenings.

content.title: Maitai Lapita Village, respect for tradition

introduction.small: The island of Huahine is home to many ancient relics, and its rich past and culture the hotel honours by ensuring travellers have the warmest welcome possible.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maitai Lapita Village, respect for tradition

paragraphs.text:
The Maitai hotel keeps its promise. Its name means 'all is well' in Tahitian. Indeed, vacations here are always a success in this little hamlet, which combines a restaurant, swimming pool and 32 air-conditioned bungalows set on the banks of a small lake or in the heart of a botanical garden. The architecture is reminiscent of traditional Polynesian houses, including ancient shelters for pirogues. Several display windows also show everyday objects and ornaments of the Lapita culture found in 1970 during excavations.

Other archaeological sites can be visited on Huahine, and you can also tour by pirogue. Unless you prefer horse-riding or cycling…

The hotel offers a diverse array of activities, like scuba-diving, sea kayaking and snorkelling. Another asset of the establishment: it was one of the very first to commit to EarthCheck environmental and social control. On a daily basis, Maitai Lapita Village endeavours to reduce water and electricity consumption, as well as manage waste production. Furthermore, environmental operations are regularly undertaken to educate and train the staff in sustainable development and ecogestures.

content.title: Kia Ora Hotel & Spa, the sea & I

introduction.small: Amidst the heavenly setting of a coconut grove on the atoll of Rangiroa, you will gaze at the clear blue waters of the lagoon that spreads right at the front door of your small Polynesian house.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kia Ora Hotel & Spa, the sea & I

paragraphs.text:
Rangiroa and its white sandy beaches, blue lagoon and coconut trees… Every element of Kia Ora Resort & Spa's decor is straight out of a postcard. This is where you will find the hotel bungalows, forming a small Polynesian village. They all have their own specific features: one offers a Jacuzzi, another one a swimming pool… Unusual, one of the bungalows is even built on stilts. From its terrace, you will be able to dive right into the crystal-clear waters. Those who prefer adventure to idleness will choose among the various sports activities available: canoeing, dugout canoeing, snorkelling, for instance, allowing you to explore the coral reefs amidst a lagoon famous for its diving spots. Those reefs line the deserted beaches, populated only by coconut trees, whose shade on the white sand provide blessed relief from the sun. Live a truly unique experience back to the source, at the end of the world and out of time!

content.title: On the waterfront at the Blue Banana

introduction.small: Tables on a pontoon, French and Polynesian flavours on the plate, a clear view of the ocean on the horizon... the Blue Banana has it all.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the waterfront at the Blue Banana

paragraphs.text:
The Blue Banana boasts an exquisite panorama, with the lagoon in the foreground and the island of Moorea in the background. The sea breeze will softly cool you off, while your thoughts get lost in the beautiful landscape. The terrace appears to float on the water. The voyage, however, is entirely at the table, with a menu that ranges from French Polynesian to classic French, with a side trip through Italy via a genuine pizza oven set up on the terrace, the "Blue Banana" pizza naturally being the house special. Beside the menu, a blackboard presents the various specials, introduced to you by Steve and Capucine, captains of this boat anchored in Punaauia.

If you wish to observe the delicate ballet of manta rays during dinner, make sure to book a table on the pontoon above the lagoon beforehand.

introduction.small: The island of the Tuamotu Archipelago enjoys an international reputation among divers and is one of the largest atolls in the world.

paragraphs.text:
Rangiroa means "endless sky" in Polynesian, and the lagoon seems equally unlimited. 80km long and 32km wide, it is considered one of the very best spots to come across aquatic life. Whatever your level of diving, you will encounter a thousand and one wonders to explore underwater, whether with an oxygen tank or simply with flippers, mask and snorkel. It justly deserves its reputation as a "paradise for divers".

The Tiputa and Avatoru passes, which cut through the barrier reef and the reef slopes in particular are home to an absolutely extraordinary flora and fauna, with a wealth of colours and unique shapes. Dolphins, hammerhead sharks, rays, surgeon and napoleon fish, barracudas, turtles… Pinch yourself: this is not a dream.

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/rangiroa-holiday/

introduction.small: Opened in 1979, this was the first restaurant-bar on Bora Bora, with five tables on the sand. Today, it is a gourmet institution, drawing tourists from around the world.

paragraphs.text:
Bloody Mary's reputation is already history. It has served its signature drink to Harrison Ford, Pierce Brosnan, Gerard Depardieu and Keanu Reeves, along with no shortage of famous athletes and singers - Ron Wood of the Rolling Stones played a concert here. Even astronauts: Buzz Aldrin once pulled up a stool at the bar, long after his first steps on the moon.

The attraction? Besides the cocktail, the local fish and seafood of the day (except on Sunday), guaranteed fresh as you will be able to take your pick directly off the stalls covered in crushed ice.

The atmosphere is inspired by the traditional Polynesian construction in coconut wood and bamboo. Feet in the sand, enjoy the simple and unadulterated flavours of Polynesian fishing. The place is now so popular that you will definitely need a reservation for dinner.

Bloody Mary's

introduction.small: This island in the Society archipelago is the centre of the Polynesian world from where the first Ma'ohi went out to conquer the Pacific. Glorious relics of the past remain.

paragraphs.text:
A sacred island for all Polynesians, Raiatea is said to have appeared first, and it has retained its authenticity and mystical aura. Birthplace of the Ma'ohi civilisation and once seat of political and religious powers in all of Polynesia, the island is home to large number of marae between Mount Temehani and its natural beaches. Discover the remains of various places of worship that tell of an unknown part of history. Among them, a true witness of this prestigious past is the royal marae of Taputapuatea, the largest Polynesian sanctuary, is a vestige of this glorious past. It still stands, facing the sea, with its rows of engraved coral slabs.

It brought together senior dignitaries from archipelagos near and far, their large canoes taking the sacred Ava Moa pass to cross the lagoon. To commemorate their cultural roots, Hawaiians, New Zealanders and Cook Island inhabitants still perform the pilgrimage to the archaeological site, which Polynesians revere.

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/raiatea-holiday/

content.title: Aranui V, all aboard for the Marquises

introduction.small: The cargo ship is an excellent way to make one's way slowly to the Marquesas Islands, remote Pacific treasures fortunately reachable by this amazing boat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aranui V, all aboard for the Marquises

paragraphs.text:
The cruise is anything but banal: people on board consists of various travellers, from Marquesas returning to their homeland, to itinerant workers and travellers taking short cuts. The entire trip, a loop from Tahiti, lasts 14 13 days, but it is possible to perform only a part. The ship sails the vastness of the Pacific, making stops in the Marquesas islands, which are otherwise difficult to access, and where tourism is underdeveloped: thanks to the Aranui V, which delivers freight to these remote spots, they can now be visited very easily.

The loading and unloading in itself is fascinating, as are the Marquesas' deep valleys, sacred temples, and artisanal crafts. No need to search for an address to spend the night, the 126m ship has comfortable cabins with full board, pool and gym.

Aranui V

introduction.small: Popular destinations for surfers, Tahiti and its sister island Moorea have many great surfing spots, especially at Teahupoo village.

paragraphs.text:
Teahupoo on the southwestern coast of the Tahitian peninsula is one of the world's best surf spots. The waves are huge and impressive. They form when the ocean comes up against the reef, generating huge and fearsome tubes. The danger lies in the coral reef just below the mountain of water. Daredevils soar on their board, which seem so fragile against the powerful waves. Not a soul has forgotten the famous American free surfer, Laird Hamilton, who challenged a 15-metre-high wall of water here in 2000! The record has yet to be broken. The wave is legendary, but access will be restricted to professionals… Rest assured, you will be able to enjoy the show put on by the very best surfers in the world. On the beach, an old longboard, on which the names of everyone who conquered the wave have been inscribed, points to the skies.

Every August, the Billabong Pro, a World Surf League event, feeds the myth of Teahupoo.

Teahupoo
98722 Taiarapu-Ouest
Tahiti

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/tahitian-activities/outdoor-activities/

introduction.small: The lagoon of this island in the Tuamotu Archipelago is a UNESCO biosphere reserve to safeguard its wealth of flora and terrestrial and marine wildlife.

paragraphs.text:
Since 2006, Fakarava and a handful of neighbouring atolls belong to UNESCO's World Heritage of natural biosphere reserves. It consists of small islets and spits of white sand –even pink in places – that stretch into the vast Pacific and are hemmed by a lagoon worthy of the finest aquariums. Nature lovers bless the magnificence of Fakarava - on land and underwater.

Unfrequented by tourists, although Henri Matisse visited in the 1930s, the island's environment, untouched by pollution, hosts birds, turtles, crustaceans, many endemic and rare fish, and countless trees and plants. Divers of all levels come to admire the splendour of the underwater world, the most seasoned venturing into the Garuae Pass, off more than a kilometre and a half from the coast, densely populated with colourful corals, triggerfish, sharks, and majestic rays.

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/fakarava-holiday/

content.title: L'O à la bouche, a festival of flavours

introduction.small: L'O à la Bouche is a mouthwatering sure bet in Papeete, with cuisine performing a brilliant synthesis of French and Polynesian influences.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'O à la bouche, a festival of flavours

paragraphs.text:
This is an institution on Tahiti. Since 1994, the gastronomic restaurant run by chef Jean-Charles Lallemand has kept popular in the heart of Papeete. L'O à la Bouche has especially caught the eye with its beautiful culinary compositions, which sail between local and European influences, served in a subdued atmosphere. The foie gras with apple sauce, and the smoked duck breast in Tahiti honey share the bill with Polynesian fish such as Papio fillet served with herring caviar and creamy risotto, crab ravioli with saffron and crustacean dressing, as well as local Tahiti shrimp in coconut milk curry. Unless you indulge in bacon-wrapped scallops with nut oil. The profiteroles desserts served with vanilla and chocolate sauce are to die for. Is your mouth already watering? Then remember to book in advance, as the successful restaurant is very often completely full.

L'O à la Bouche

98713 Papeete
Tahiti

www.loalabouchetahiti.com

content.title: Green Lodge, in communion with the elements

introduction.small: On the east coast of Moorea, the guest house merges with its environment to offer a stay as close as possible to nature.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Green Lodge, in communion with the elements

paragraphs.text:
Built by the water, six wooden bungalows line the coral reef. Only a few steps separate the covered terraces available on each house from the white sandy beach. Those overlooking the luxurious garden circle the pool. All the villas have air conditioning, a bathroom decor of dark stones and a terrace where you can admire the "Mooreales" lights.

The couple who run the hotel will welcome you with kindness and attentions, offering you numerous water sports possibilities: canoeing, surfing, stand up paddle boarding, diving, kite-surfing, etc. You may also want to keep your feet dry and try inland activities: the gorgeous Moorea Golf Club is located nearby and the island can be explored on foot or on horseback.

After so much effort, unwind over lunch and dinner on site (with a reservation). And for maximum relaxation, give in to a massage at the water's edge?

Green Lodge Moorea

content.title: Le Rétro is still the place to be

introduction.small: This legendary spot on the harbour remains the best place in town for a drink or a coffee while watching the world go by.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Rétro is still the place to be

paragraphs.text:
Le Rétro: no visit to Papeete is complete without at least a few hours whiled away under its red awnings and neon lights. Centrally located on the harbour of Papeete, the establishment draws locals and travellers from morning through lunch, happy hour and on into the evening. Some like to compare it to Saint-Tropez's Café Sénéguier… only with a more exotic setting. This tavern is undoubtedly the island's go-to café with its French brasserie look. It retained a special place among locals, as many remember French American singer Joe Dassin spent his last moments there in 1980. The artists sang and loved Polynesia, and the inhabitants loved him back. A commemorative plaque has even been fitted at the entrance of Le Rétro.

Sooner or later, all visitors to Tahiti pass through its doors. Will it soon be your turn?

Le Rétro

content.title: InterContinental Tahiti Resort & Spa, a taste of paradise

introduction.small: Well situated near Papeete and its airport, this hotel pampers the newly arrived from the moment they leave the plane, with the benefit of views over Moorea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: InterContinental Tahiti Resort & Spa, a taste of paradise

paragraphs.text:
InterContinental Tahiti Resort & Spa offers rest and relaxation for body and soul. Its garden is a green haven of 12 hectares fringed by the blue lagoon and two pools. Of the 245 rooms, choose one on stilts, open to the sea like a boat ready to set sail the Polynesian islands. Unless you would rather stay in one of the higher standing panoramic rooms that offer views of the lagoon from their individual balconies. The hotel is a successful marriage of Tahitian and contemporary styles, which is mirrored in the cuisine of the two restaurants, which combine inspirations from here and elsewhere.

The gourmet restaurant on stilts is the perfect place to feast while watching the waves; the buffet room offers traditional dance performances. In the distance, Moorea Island is an invitation to continue the trip or enjoy one last sunset: Polynesia's are without rival.

content.title: InterContinental Bora Bora Resort & Thalasso Spa, the rarest pearl

introduction.small: One of the finest resorts in one of the finest locations on Bora Bora, as magnificent as the mythical island itself, for an eco-friendly stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: InterContinental Bora Bora Resort & Thalasso Spa, the rarest pearl

paragraphs.text:
The requisite elements of a five-star luxury hotel, with the attentive hospitality typical of Polynesia… This is the perfect combination, to be sumptuously enjoyed in one of the resort's 80 luxurious villas on stilts, three restaurants, three bars, and numerous boutiques around the pool. The InterContinental, along with impeccable service, here advocates an eco-tourism of the highest quality. For example, air conditioning is produced by an ecological system using sea water, much less electricity intensive.

Explore the thalassotherapy centre, the first of its kind in French Polynesia, where, through the glass floor under the massage tables, you can admire Bora Bora's beautiful marine life and enjoy special, unexpected moments. The treatment rooms open onto the lagoon. Between traditional skills and marine nutrients from the deep seas of the South Pacific Ocean, you will enjoy complete care for a feeling of absolute well-being…

InterContinental Bora Bora Resort & Thalasso Spa
Motu Piti Aau
98730 Vaitape
Bora Bora

introduction.small: This favourite Polynesian island successfully combines exuberant nature, rich cultural heritage, volcanic land forms and a lagoon that sparkles like a rough diamond.

paragraphs.text:
Huahine belongs to the Society Islands, like Tahiti, which could be considered the oldest. Indeed, this small, quiet, well-preserved island is the birthplace of the Lapita people, ancestors of the Tahitians. It has many cultural and archaeological sites (including Maeva), hence its nickname "memory island". Described as a "feminine island" because of its voluptuous curves, it divides into two parts, one large, one small. According to legend, Hiro, the divine giant, divided the land with his canoe.

Today, the inhabitants still worship the sacred blue-eyed eels of the village of Fare, which all travellers respect. They also fish according to traditional techniques by erecting stone enclosures in the lagoon that turn into fish traps. Take in Huahine's authentic atmosphere, with its white sandy beaches, bays and crystal-clear lagoon on one side, and wild and lush forests on the other.

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/huahine-holiday/

introduction.small: While Raiatea, the neighbouring island with whom it shares the lagoon, is sacred, but Taha'a is the fragrant island. Vanilla has been cultivated here since the 19th century.

paragraphs.text:
Of all the Sous-le-Vent islands, Taha'a exhales vanilla, the scents that escape the many plantations that practice the "marriage" of flowers. It is an operation with a poetic name, requiring delicate and crucial handling: to become a pod, the vanilla flower, which cannot self-pollinate, needs divine intervention. With a pollinating insect, it is merely a fruit of chance. But with human intervention, it becomes an art.

Before humans even had the idea of artificial fertilisation, they imported this orchid from Central America to the Polynesian islands in the mid-19th century. One subspecies, the Vanilla tahitensis, appeared, a spice very much appreciated by gourmets. Taha'a produces 80% of Polynesian vanilla plantation crops and many producers open their doors to show their know-how, from pollination to the drying of the pods in the sun. This is why Taha'a is "Vanilla Island".

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/tahaa-holiday/

introduction.small: From July to October, humpback whales come to breed off the Austral Islands, a sanctuary suitable to privileged cetacean observation.

paragraphs.text:
Because it does not have lagoon, Rurutu can be approached easily from the open ocean. It is therefore a popular destination during winter in the Southern hemisphere (from July to October) for humpback whales: dozens come every year to mate and give birth to calves.

Since 2002, French Polynesia has become a sanctuary for marine mammals. Among the key spots to watch cetaceans - some more than 15m long - is the island of Rurutu, which has managed to avoid all manner of pollution, including noise: it only takes a certain number of tourists at a time. Divers put on flippers, masks and snorkel to watch the animals as whales may be afraid of oxygen tanks and swim away.

If you are a whale lover, this will be a dream come true: observing the marine choreography of this protected species and listening to their love songs, in the water or from the specially equipped platforms. The emotions that surface during these incredible experiences with the whales are sure to leave any audience spellbound.

Raie Manta Club
BP 55 Avatoru
98775 Rangiroa

+689 87 72 31 45

www.raiemantaclub.com/ruru-uk.htm

introduction.small: This confetti in the Marquesas amazes travellers with its sharp peaks and steep cliffs that stand proudly in the middle of the vast ocean.

paragraphs.text:
"Volcanic arrows looking like a church bell tower", wrote Robert Louis Stevenson in 1888. Manhandled by the laws of geology, the spectacular landscape of the island draws adventurers from around the world. Despite its remoteness: Ua Pou, part of the Marquesas, the Polynesian archipelago farthest away from the continents, is 1,300 km of Tahiti. Suffice to say that the island has managed to free itself, like the wild horses that inhabit its hills, shores and valleys.

A wind of freedom blows also on the creativity of artists who live here: musicians, painters, sculptors, and dancers. They find inspiration in the incredible landscapes, dominated by two basaltic columns, rising to over 1,200 m. They are called the entrance pillars to the house of God, for the divine has to chime in to such beauty…

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/marquesas-islands-holiday/

introduction.small: More remote and picturesque than other neighbouring islands, Maupiti is just as heavenly. The promise of a break from tourist frenzy, for globetrotters who want to get off the beaten track.

paragraphs.text:
Travellers on the tranquil shores of Maupiti stroll and daydream. Over 11 sqkm, the tiny island counts preserved spectacular fauna and flora, as well as a genuine Polynesian way of life. This is the island for bike tours and canoe rides. With a guide, climb to the top of Mount Teurafaatiu - over 370m- and embrace the panorama of dazzling splendour.

Another site you need to absolutely explore is the Vaitia Valley, legendary place where an imposing flat rock is the supposed remnant of the canoe of Hiro, the great hero and demigod who divided Huahine, another Sous-le-Vent island in the Society Islands.

The sumptuous Maupiti lagoon and its jade colours offer beautiful deep-sea diving, where manta rays love to swim.

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/maupiti/

introduction.small: Before exploring other Polynesian archipelagos, why not start with a discovery of Tahiti's wild side? With a tree house as a base camp...

paragraphs.text:
Tahiti's peninsula is rarely part of the usual routes frequented by visitors recently converted to Polynesia. However, its inhabitants know the richness and authenticity of this nature destination, where the mountain meets the ocean. Suspended between is Vanira Lodge, a gorgeous cluster of wooden bungalows in the middle of the rainforest. They dominate the village of Teahupoo, renowned among surfers for its legendary waves. Although it offers a swimming pool and a restaurant, this is not a hotel but rather a guest house serving traditional local Polynesian fare.

Each has a private bathroom, some have whirlpool, and even a kitchenette. You will feel like you're living at the end of the world, even though Papeete is only an hour-and-a-half drive away. Kayaking and hiking will allow you to push even further the feeling of getting away from it all.

Vanira Lodge
Teahupoo
98719 Taravao
Tahiti

+689 40 57 70 18

www.vaniralodge.com/index_en.php?nx=ACC

Rooms: from 15,000 XPF

introduction.small: Rangiroa winery produces Tahiti's only wine - three whites and a rosé. The vineyard, planted on a sea-islet motu, can be visited by appointment.

paragraphs.text:
The magnificent underwater scenery of the island of Rangiroa inspires raptures of the deep. But another nod to its marine riches is the names of the wines produced by the Dominique Auroy vineyard, off the village of Avatoru, in the Tuamotu Archipelago: White Reef, Reef Clos, Rosé nacarat and other sweet white wines. An original land to grow grapes, far from usual winemaking territories! Several years of work and experimentation were necessary to acclimatising the vine stocks.

Today, the vineyard of over eight hectares in the middle of a coconut grove produces two annual harvests (in May and November) and 40,000 bottles a year, all of which age in the cellars.

Accessible by private boat, the domain can be visited and holds wine-tastings. Make a reservation and try these wines structured in flavour by Carignan, Hamburg and Italia Muscat vines, even though they are grown in the midst of the Pacific Ocean! To be enjoyed in moderation, of course.

Domaine Dominique Auroy
98776 Rangiroa

https://www.vindetahiti.com/spip.php?page=onepage.en&lang=en

introduction.small: The Pearl Museum reveals the history and secrets of creating the iconic jewel of French Polynesia, and its complex and fascinating process.

paragraphs.text:
Pay a free visit to this small museum founded by Robert Wan, who runs several pearl farms in Polynesia. You will know all about the origins of the black pearl of Tahiti. Its colour comes from the black-lipped oyster that produces it: the Pinctada margaritifera, an endemic Polynesian species.

The dark pigment it releases gives the dark colour to the nacre it secretes. For the oyster to produce a pearl, we must encourage nature by putting a tiny ball into the mollusc. It reacts by surrounding it with layers of nacre, turning the foreign body into a pearl. The Japanese invented the technique over a hundred years ago. Discover the craft and its history through civilisations (Egyptian and Pre-Colombian among others), representations through art as well as the process behind the creation of these gems. The museum also exhibits the largest round pearl in Tahiti, weighing over 8.6g 8,7g and measuring 26mm in diameter.

Robert Wan Pearl Museum
Boulevard Pomare
BP 850
98714 Papeete
Tahiti

+689 40 54 86 40

content.title: Rurutu and the cave of the ogress

introduction.small: Rurutu island, raised from the seabed by geological movement, has limestone caves on its shores whose bizarrely shaped columns have inspired legends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rurutu and the cave of the ogress

paragraphs.text:
To explore the maze of cliff-side caves on Rurutu island, curious explorers and speleologists only need to follow the guide! About thirty caves are therefore perched up above the ocean and hide spectacular thousand-year-old stalactites and stalagmites. Genuine natural treasures, their coral and volcanic walls sparkle when light shines through!

Caves often communicate, sink into the dried coral rock, and offer a route punctuated by dreamlike shapes or strange natural sculptures that free the imagination and arouse extravagant metaphors.

One Polynesian myths relates that ogress lived in the Ina cave: her long fingers and nails possess magical powers. The inhabitants of Rurutu are renowned for their basketry and weaving, especially mats. Their complicated interlacing is reminiscent of the underground network of the island, a mysterious and sacred world filled with ancient burial tombs.

introduction.small: The Papeete Roulottes – food trucks à la Polynesian – are a popular dinner destination in the city centre.

paragraphs.text:
This is where it happens at night in the heart of Papeete. The animation is in full swing on the harbour parking lot, around dozens of street restaurants, which prepare, on the spot or take away, pizza, pancakes and crepes, Asian specialties such as noodle soup and chow mein, and traditional Polynesian dishes with raw fish. These roulottes, as they are called, open up as soon as the sun goes down and stay open until late into the night.

Authenticity is key on Vaiete square, usually populated by both locals and tourists. Small prices and friendliness are part of the charm conveyed by these typical food trucks, which come in handy for dinner on the go. Families and groups of friends merrily share meals at the nearby tables in a joyful hubbub.

On weekends, concerts add even more atmosphere to this popular, warm and upbeat spot, akin to the Polynesian people themselves.

Les Roulottes
Place Vaiete
98714 Papeete
Tahiti

content.title: The Museum of Tahiti and the islands: a voyage through time

introduction.small: Te Fare Manaha is the preamble to an exploration of Tahiti and its neighbours, some quite distant, to better understand and appreciate Polynesian culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Museum of Tahiti and the islands: a voyage through time

paragraphs.text:
The location of this historic and ethnographic museum owes nothing to chance. A large marae, a sacred place of the Ma'ohi, ancestors of the Tahitians, once stood near the lagoon, near the Nu'uroa Tip. Among archaeological finds and natural and cultural heritage collections, visitors embrace Polynesian traditions, like tikis - anthropomorphic sculptures - the ancient canoes on display outside the museum. In total, around 30,000 items from the Oceanian Continent are on display.

On the outside, take a walk along the ethnobotanical path in the park - it is a nearly five-hectare conservatory of endemic plants. Each species – some being endangered – has a special meaning and specific uses in Polynesian rituals. Their names evoke the mysteries of nature: paper mulberry, kava or Piper methysticum, banyans 'ora and Ficus prolixa - indigenous Marquesan plants. Every Tuesday morning, the museum programs guided tours of the nearby gardens, an ideal way to discover the sacred, therapeutic or nutritious values of these plants.

Museum of Tahiti and the islands
Pointe des pêcheurs
Nu'uroa, Punaauia
98718 Tamanu
Tahiti

+689 40 54 84 35

www.museetahiti.pf/?lang=en

introduction.small: The pearls of Rangiroa are famous: many farms cultivate this jewel of the Pacific, taking over from the fishermen who used to dive here for pearls.

paragraphs.text:
Oro, the generous sky god, offered men the black pearl of Tahiti. It is cultivated today in several islands of the Tuamotu Archipelago, which has about 250 pearl farms. Rangiroa (Gauguin's Pearl) is the best known. For man, eager and fascinated by this beautiful rarity, could not be content with the fruit of chance, when he went on an adventure to uncover hidden treasures.

Today, pearl farming, developed in Japan, brings more luck, but demands just as much skill and perseverance. Discover the craft behind pearl farming, which Tahiti pearls originate from, during a guided tour of the farm. There are various stages to be observed, like sliding a ball into the oyster's reproductive system, around which will form layers of nacre. Learn about the slow process during which the shellfish live strung together in the ocean. You may even end your visit at the farm's shop where pearls are harvested and turned into gorgeous jewellery.

Rangiroa Pearl Farm (Gauguin's Pearl)
BP 191 Avatoru
98775 Rangiroa

+689 40 93 11 30

www.gauguinspearl.com

content.title: The Monoi route, a wellness destination

introduction.small: Divided into 22 areas throughout Tahiti, with an additional four on Moorea, this itinerary guides you to this must-have Polynesian beauty product.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Monoi route, a wellness destination

paragraphs.text:
The ancestors knew how to take care of their body: the Ma'ohi used coconut oil and tiaré flower, the latter the symbol of Tahiti, and macerated it to concoct a sacred balm that is still used today. The balm became commercialised in 1942. Today there are two different preparation methods: artisanal, which families and villages have maintained, and industrial. The "Monoi de Tahiti Appellation of Origin" seal guarantees the authenticity of the ingredients and their content.

To discover the trade secrets and moisturising and reparative properties of Monoi, which is just as effective on skin as on hair, take a Monoi tour comprised of 22 stops, and visit producers, artisans, massage centres, spas, botanical gardens, perfumeries, plantations and more… The beauty ritual unfolds before you, revealing its abundant raw materials (tiaré and coconut) and relaxation rituals.

www.iles-polynesie.fr/monoi.php

content.title: Taha'a by Pearl Resorts, like living in a chateau

introduction.small: More than a hotel, a stay at this true jewel set among diamond-clear waters and golden beaches is an unforgettable experience. Polynesia in all its splendour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Taha'a by Pearl Resorts, like living in a chateau

paragraphs.text:
This Relais & Châteaux establishment displays its magnificence on a private motu (islet of coral sand) off Taha'a. The refinement of the sublime spa, the elegance of the 45 suites and 12 villas on the water, the tailored service and exceptional welcome contribute to the excellence of this truly unique experience. Top-notch gastronomy completes this daydream, three restaurants unveiling fusion cuisine between French and Polynesian traditions. Enjoy a snack on the white sandy beach or multi-course full dinner for a romantic experience. Whether a luxuriant siesta under the palms or a marine odyssey around the small island, all pleasures and every whim will be answered.

What is certain is that, just installed, you will be overwhelmed by the desire to never leave this perfect illustration of earthly paradise. However, on the horizon, Bora Bora's steep silhouette calls to you to set out on new adventures.

Le Taha'a by Pearl Resorts

Pātio
98733 Taha'a

+689 40 50 76 01

introduction.small: The Moorea Dolphin Center at the InterContinental hotel enables you to get up close and personal with these marine mammals, and even to swim among them in the lagoon's crystal-clear waters.

paragraphs.text:
It is impossible not to fall in love with beautiful Hina, twirling Kuokoa and his half-brother Lokahi. These three dolphins are about 2.70m long and just over 200 kilos, but they are very hospitable to all their visitors, even the youngest dolphin, who is barely two years old.

Residents of the Marine Mammal Protection Centre, these are bottlenose dolphins (Tursiops truncates). Fun, educational programs teach you about their lives and their environment in the respect of their daily lives. The centre based its programs on observing the animals in their natural habitat, and interactions with visitors are time-limited in order to preserve them.

Select the complete package and you will be able to swim alongside dolphins for more than an hour though. Go for a dive that will leave you with strong emotions and a lasting memory.

Moorea Dolphin Center
Hôtel InterContinental Moorea
98729 Papetoai
Moorea

+689 40 56 38 76

https://www.mooreadolphin.com/en/

introduction.small: Hiva Oa, the best known of the Marquesas Islands, has welcomed many illustrious guests: Paul Gauguin, Jacques Brel, Herman Melville, Pierre Loti…

paragraphs.text:
Great artists have been able to express the immense emotion that captures visitors to the Marquesas. Paul Gauguin and Jacques Brel, who both rest for eternity in the cemetery of Atuona, passed the end of their life in Hiva Oa, finding inspiration here for their latest creations.

"Due to a lack of wind, time stops in the Marquesas", wrote Brel, a beautiful metaphor for the unique and magical atmosphere of the island, whose steep peaks and cliffs, large bays, and valleys never fail to impress travellers. Artisans here continue the tradition of tiki making - human-shaped sculptures carved in stone, wood or coral. Iipona has the biggest in all of Polynesia. While at Taaoa, under the tropical almond, Tahitian chestnut and banyan trees, other cultural and religious relics can be admired, in the imposing shadow of the 1,300-metre-high Mount Temetiu.

https://tahititourisme.uk/en-gb/islands-of-tahiti/marquesas-islands-holiday/

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Tahiti
content.introduction: Located in the north of Tahiti, Papeete has a very mild tropical climate. The trade winds blow a constant and pleasant temperature. Both seasons of the island (wet and dry) are temperate with little variation. The average annual temperature in Papeete is 27°C (80.6°F).

airports.title: Tahiti Faa'a International Airport
airports.description:
The Tahiti Faa'a International Airport is located about 5 km (about 3 miles) southeast of Papeete.
  • 2 terminals:
    • T1 (domestic flights)
    • International terminal (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Papeete and back:
  • By car
    • From the Tahiti International airport, it takes about 10 minutes to reach Papeete city centre via Boulevard de la Reine Pōmare IV.
    • At the airport, two parking lots are available to travellers: one Express car park (P1) for mid-stay parking, and one Long Stay car park (P2).
      - Parking in P1 costs XPF 200 for 30 minutes, XPF 220 for between 30 minutes and 1 hour, and XPF 440 for between 1 and 2 hours - Parking in P2 costs XPF 150 for 15 minutes to 1 hour (the first 15 minutes are free), then XPF 300 for between 1 and 2 hours and XPF 800 for 24 hours.
    • Many car rental companies have counters near the International terminal. Rates from XPF 5,500/day.
  • By Bus/Truck
    • Bus lines run at a frequency of 20 minutes from the airport to downtown Papeete. It costs about XPF 200. An increase of 50 to 70% applies between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., and on Sundays and holidays.
    • For buses and 'trucks', the stop is in front of the international terminal, across the parking lot.
  • By Taxi
    • A taxi stand is located at the exit of T1 (the domestic terminal). The drive from the airport to the centre of Papeete lasts around 10 minutes and costs about XPF 2,000 (night fare is about XPF 2,500).
  • Services: bars and restaurants, boutiques, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), luggage storage.
  • Telephone: +689 40 86 60 60
  • Website: www.tahiti-aeroport.pf

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Tahiti
transportation.description: The car is the ideal mode of transport to explore the island, though some sites are not accessible by vehicle, at which point it is possible to rent a bike. Public transport options exist, but unfortunately they are not widespread and poorly organised; buses and trucks, however, are the means of transport most commonly used by locals. Hitchhiking is also very common.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic French phrases that will make your stay in Tahiti a little easier:
phrases: I don't understand: Je ne comprends pas
What time is it?: Quelle heure est-il ?
How much is (…)?: Quel est le prix de (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Tahiti
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Papeete each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 1: New Year (national)
events.description: The opportunity to experience the Tere Fā'ati the annual Polynesian ritual of shared happiness. Programme: Island tour in ‘trucks' (traditional bus covered with flowers), music, dance, swimming, food tasting and local fruits.

events.title: March 5: Day of the Gospel or Day of the Missionaries (local)
events.description: Religious festival and public holiday in French Polynesia, commemorating the arrival of Protestant missionaries from the London Missionary Society in Matavai Bay (5 March 1797).

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national)
events.description: Christian religious festival whose date varies. On the programme: chocolate treasure hunt in the city, games and workshops for children.

events.title: April 28: Commemoration of the arrival of the Bounty (Bounty Day)
events.description: Large annual gathering: descendants of the Bounty mutineers, the British frigate that landed on April 28, 1789, gather on the island of Tubuai. Books and archival footage tell the story of the first Europeans who arrived on the island.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory of 1945 (national)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (national)
events.description: During this hugely popular festival, also known as World Music Day, all sorts of free concerts are held in Papeete's streets and parks. Fun, party vibes are guaranteed!

events.title: June 29: Day of autonomy (local)
events.description: This French Polynesian holiday celebrates the day in 1880 when King Pomare V donated his States to France.

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Papeete, it is also the occasion for the Heiva i Tahiti celebrations. On the programme: songs and traditional dances in honour of the island.

events.title: Third weekend in September : European Heritage Days (national)
events.description: During the European Heritage Days, free guided tours are offered at the Museum of Tahiti and the Islands, including around the herbarium and reserve collections that are usually closed to the public.

events.title: November 1: All soul's day (national)
events.description: The custom of All Saints (Turamara'a) is required under the sun. This is the day when the Tahitians pay homage to their ancestors. The graves are flowered, and brightened with paint or white sand.

events.title: November 11: Armistice Day (national)
events.description: On this day, citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 25: Christmas (national)
events.description: The Christmas holidays are celebrated all over the island, houses are decorated and the children eagerly await the opening of their presents. A large Christmas market is held in downtown Papeete.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Papeete, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the territory of Papeete
administrativeProcedures.description:
Contrary to other overseas departments, overseas territories are not part of the Schengen area. An identity card is therefore not sufficient for European residents. You will need a passport valid for a period of at least 6 months after leaving French Polynesia.

Warning: in case of a stopover in the US, check that your passport meets US standards, that is to say, it is a valid biometric or electronic passport (for more information, visit the website of the Embassy of the United States: https://fr.usembassy.gov/).
If this is not the case, ask for a transit visa at the US consulate.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: There is no daylight savings time in Tahiti
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping

In Papeete, like in all French Polynesia, a supplement for restaurant and café servers is already included in the bill. However, it is customary to leave a tip when you are satisfied with the service.
